Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Studies of Electroweak and Hadronic Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Wayne W. Repko at Michigan State University.

These activities include the development of a more accurate theoretical description of a class of particles known as heavy quarkonia --- bound states of a heavy quark and its antiquark. Quarkonium systems of this type are formed in various excited energy levels, and gradually decay to the state of lowest energy in much the same way an excited hydrogen atom decays. However, the critical difference is that the decays of quarkonium, unlike the decays of hydrogen, necessarily include the effects of the strong nuclear force. Along with collaborators, Professor Repko has developed models that describe these heavy-quark systems, and as part of this research project he will now refine these models with the involvement of students. Another topic that Professor Repko will investigate is the nature of the mixing that describes how neutrinos with different masses are experimentally observed. This type of mixing is a purely quantum-mechanical phenomenon that has important implications for matter formation in the early universe.

This project will also have several broader impacts. It will involve both undergraduate physics majors and physics graduate students who will work on various aspects of the research descibed above. The undergraduates will engage with some of the computing aspects of this project and thereby obtain an introduction to theoretical physics research. The graduate student(s) will be more deeply involved and receive critical training that will aid in their professional development. There is also likely to be a crossover of research results into new classroom topics during the duration of this grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds from this grant were used to support theoretical studies involving cosmology, Quantum Chromodynamic (QCD) corrections to structure of heavy quark-antiquark mesons that can be thought of as similar to hydrogen atoms, decay properties of the recently discovered Higgs boson, the prospect of measuring additional properties of the Higgs boson by studying the production of Higgs boson pairs at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the structure of the mixing mechanism that governs the way the electron, muon and tau neutrinos behave. All of these studies were performed with the help of undergraduate research assistants in addition to one or another of my senior collaborators.

The cosmology research extended earlier work on the way gravitational waves in the early universe interact with the neutrinos that are also present. This behavior was understood for relatively high energy (short wave length) gravitational waves, but the gravitational wave - neutrino interaction was not completely understood for long wave lengths. In collaboration with undergraduate Benjamin Stefanek, we were able to obtain an analytical solution for the long wave length case and publish the result.

The QCD corrections to the heavy quarkonia involved including higher order contributions to the quark-antiquark potential energy and seeing how this affected the properties of the mesons. This work was a collaboration that included undergraduates Marco Santia and Noah Green along with Stan Radford, a senior collaborator from the State University of New York, Brockport. In the equal mass case, we found that a very satisfactory description of the mesons known as charmonium (charm-anticharm) and upsilon (bottom-antibotton) could be obtained with the inclusion of the additional QCD corrections. The study of unequal mass mesons is currently under investigation.

Investigation of the mixing of neutrinos was a collaboration including Andrew Hanlon, an undergraduate, and senior collaborators Shao-Feng Ge and Duane Dicus of the University of Texas Austin. Neutrinos, once believed to be massless, were found to have small masses. This allows the three neutrino types to mix with one another. The mixing can be described in terms of four parameters, three of which have been measured in a variety of experiments. With the current set of experiments, the fourth is quite difficult to measure. We proposed a symmetry that relates this parameter to the other three in a probabilistic fashion. The most probable value is predicted to be very closed to the preliminary experimental results.

The Higgs boson studies were carried out with Dicus and Chung Kao of the University of Oklahoma. For the decay H → e ebar γ , we showed that it can provide an additional test of whether the Higgs boson has standard model couplings or is something different. The Higgs pair production study was an attempt to determine if it is feasible to measure the Higgs boson self interaction at the LHC. Our conclusion was that this is extremely difficult and the task will be equally difficult at future colliders with substaintially higher energy.
